demos.abstract:
With the emergence of Open Source relational databases as well as a plethora of NoSQL database options,, enterprises are actively seeking to leverage the lower costs and higher flexibility and scalability of these new options and moving away from proprietary technologies that locked them into endless upgrade cycles and high licensing costs.
Accion Labs has successfully helped clients to migrate their data out of such proprietary databases into open source database platforms including relational databases as well as NoSQL databases. Further, Accion Labs has provided ongoing technical support for maintenance and administration of such databases, with the required service level guarantees that enterprises need for mission critical applications.
However, the decision to migrate away from a proven database is not easy, and enterprises often stick to an existing  compromise to avoid the complex task of migration to a new alternative. This white paper attempts to address some of the concerns that enterprises have in adopting such open source alternatives, and also provides some case studies to demonstrate successful migration by various enterprises.
demos.description: A technical white paper that illustrates with case studies, how enterprises can migrate away from proprietary databases with huge licensing costs and endless upgrade cycles to a mix of open source databases - both relational as well as NoSQL
demos.title: Embracing Open Source Databases

slides.title: Determinants of the Re-engineering Approach
bullets: -Size of the system/product
--Screens, Data model, Reports, Interfaces, Data
-Source and target platform
-Goals of the re-engineering
--Performance, scalability, configurability, etc
-Extent of UI changes
--Same UI, same with architectural enhancements (JSF, Ajax), or completely different
-Approach of application development
--OOAD, MVC, SOA, MDA, MDD, etc.

slides.title: Determinants of the Re-engineering Approach (contd..)
bullets: -Type of framework deployedt
--Spring, Hibernate, Struts, Velocity, etc
-Use of other components
--BPM, BRMS,BAM, EAI, BI, etc
-Delivery methodology adopted
--Agile, RUP, Watergile, etc
-Extent of Functional Changes to the system/product

slides.title: Determinants of the Re-engineering Approach (contd..)
bullets: -Extent of configurability and customizability expected
-Extent of changes to the Data Model
-Extent of Reuse from old to new
-Third-party components in old and new platform
Extent of QA activities
-Can old test plans be reused? Can old test data, test scripts be reused?

slides.title: Key Design/Approach Considerations
bullets: -Phasing strategy
--By module, by layer, by user-type, by market, etc
-Reuse strategy
--Extent of desired/required reuse
-Presentation prototype
--Do we need a presentation prototype to guide UI design or the old is a good representation?
-Change management
--How do we sync the ongoing changes to the legacy system to the in-progress new system?

slides.title: Key Design/Approach Considerations (contd..)
bullets: -Architecture validation
--Does the architecture need validation in the new environment?
-Reference Architecture
--Develop a reference architecture before any “real” development occurs
-Interim integration strategy
--Bridge between “old” and “new”

slides.title: Key Design/Approach Considerations (contd..)
bullets: -Core object management strategy (in the interim)
--e.g. Requisition, Order, Invoice, etc
-Master data management strategy
--e.g. Customer, Supplier, Product Type, etc
-Data migration strategy
--Automated vs manual vs mixed, one-time and ongoing
-Best Practices
--Extensible Architecture, Prevent Silos, Avoid vendor lock-in, etc

--Size the effort and develop a high-level plan
-Activities
--Participate in product demos, architecture overview sessions
--Develop sizing worksheet and perform complexity analysis
--Conduct “envisioning” sessions to understand functional/technical changes
--Discuss phasing strategy and list/detail each iteration/wave and determine if it will be development or production milestone

slides.title: Initial Planning (contd..)
bullets: -Deliverables

slides.title: Main Reverse Engineering

---Main flow

slides.title: Main Reverse Engineering (contd..

slides.title: Architecture Definition

slides.title: Reference Architecture Development

slides.title: Reference Architecture Development (contd..)

slides.title: Test Planning

-Activities

slides.title: Iteration/Wave – Requirements/Design/Development/Test

slides.title: Accion Re-engineering: Best Practices
bullets: -Have a detailed plan for knowledge Acquisition of existing systems
-Have a clear re-engineering approach at the architecture level
-In case of Cloud/SaaS products/Applications create cost models based on traffic, interfaces, usage, storage, instances etc.
-Have a plan for database and data
-Choose a development methodology that is suitable for all the teams involved

slides.title: Accion Re-engineering Best Practices (contd..)
bullets: -Accion Lead to act as the glue between the various teams involved
-Capture all the not functional criteria clearly and test cases to be built for each ofthem
-Reusability of existing assets and third party tools should be considered where possible
-Have a plan to extract test data from the old systems and transform to the new format as necessary
-The customers/users should be deeply involved in creating the UAT test cases

slides.title: Cloud/SaaS Migration Considerations
bullets: -Some vendors use proprietary technologies that may require tightly coupled integrations
-Keep SLAs in consideration while deciding on the Architecture
-Regulatory Compliance (HIPAA, PCI, SEC) may need special considerations during SaaS migration/architecture
-The complexity of the environment may greatly be impacted by the number of application tiers and components being used
-Security Policies and ACL migration needs to be considered at the design time
Integration to back-office systems and external API will need special consideration

slides.title: Cloud/SaaS Migration Considerations (contd..)
bullets: -Selection of private/public/hybrid cloud
-Configurations to manage flexible routing approaches and minimize transaction delays
-Architecture decides the operational costs – a thorough mathematical model needs to be developed for the given architecture, usage, traffic etc
-Utilizing the right storage model for the various needs to prevent loss of data and minimize cost

demos.title: Oodebe
demos.description: A platform that provides a ready-to-use middleware layer to abstract away the complexity of implementing a Polyglot Persistence application
demos.abstract: Applications today need to handle a multitude of data types ranging from structured to unstructured data. Polyglot Persistence is quickly emerging as the preferred architecture for such applications. Oodebe provides a simple, flexible, scalable and extensible solution for Polyglot Persistence

slides.title: Polyglot Persistence - An Introduction
slides.subtitle: How to choose a database when building an application from the multitude of SQL and NoSQL options available

slides.title: Factors affecting the choice of the database

blocks.title: Data Models
bullets: What type of data sources do we want to integrate?
How do we want to manipulate / analyze the data?
What is the volume, variety and velocity of data?

blocks.title: Consistency, Availability, Partitioning (CAP)
bullets: Consistency: Only one value of an object to each client (Atomicity)
Availability: Each client can always read and write (Low Latency)
Partition Tolerance: The system works well despite physical network partitions (Horizontal Scalability)
What are the CAP use cases that the application needs to handle?

slides.title: Data Models Comparison
slides.subtitle: Examples, Capabilities, Applications and Limitations of various data models

bullets: The simplest model where each object is retrieved with a unique key, with values having no inherent model
Utilize in-memory storage to provide fast access with optional persistence
Other data models built on top of this model to provide more complex objects
blocks.title: Capabilities

bullets: Applications requiring fast access to a large number of objects, such as caches or queues
Applications that require fast-changing data environments like mobile, gaming, online ads
blocks.title: Applications

bullets: Cannot update subset of a value
Does not provide querying
As number of objects becomes large, generating unique keys could become complex
blocks.title: Limitations

bullets: Extension of key-value model, where value is a structured document
Documents can be highly complex, hierarchical data structures without requiring pre-defined 'schema'
Supports queries on structured documents
Search platforms are also document-oriented
blocks.title: Capabilities

bullets: Applications that need to manage a large variety of objects that differ in structure
Large product catalogs in e-commerce, customer profiles, content management applications
blocks.title: Applications

bullets: No standard query syntax
Query performance not linearly scalable
Join queries across collections not efficient
blocks.title: Limitations

bullets: Extension of key-value model, where the value is a set of columns (column-family)
A column can have multiple time-stamped versions
Columns can be generated at run-time and not all rows need to have all columns
blocks.title: Capabilities

bullets: Storing a large number of time-stamped data like event logs, sensor data
Analytics that involve querying entire columns of data such as trends or time series analytics
blocks.title: Applications

bullets: No join queries or sub-queries
Limited support for aggregation
Ordering is done per partition, specified at table creation time
blocks.title: Limitations

bullets: Models graphs consisting of nodes and edges with properties (meta-data) describing them
Implement very fast graph traversal operations
Also support indexing of meta data to enable graph traversal combined with search queries
blocks.title: Capabilities

bullets: Applications that deal with objects with a large number of inter-relations
Applications like social networking friends-networks, hierarchical role based permissions, complex decision trees, maps, network topologies
blocks.title: Applications

bullets: Difficult to scale for large data sets for generic graphs
Giraph uses the Bulk Synchronous Parallel model to overcome some of the scalability limitations
blocks.title: Limitations

bullets: Conventional RDBMS structure consisting of fixed schema with ACID properties
Provides well documented and widely supported SQL syntax
Capable of complex queries including subqueries and joins
blocks.title: Capabilities

bullets: Transactional data applications like ERP, CRM, Banking etc.
Applications where data volume is limited and schema are by and large fixed
blocks.title: Applications

bullets: Lacks horizontal scalability and hence limited in handling 'big data'
Not efficient at handling complex multi-level nested data
Cannot handle “unstructured” data where structure is not known at design time
blocks.title: Limitations

slides.title: Conclusion 1:
slides.subtitle: No single database can address all data types

blockcontent.paragraph: Compromise: Application unable to integrate multiple data types

slides.title: Conclusion 2:
slides.subtitle: No single database can address all CAP use cases

blockcontent.paragraph: Compromise: To get horizontal scalability application must give up Consistency (Atomicity) or Availability (Low Latency)

blocks.title: Use multiple databases
bullets: No single database can address all data types and CAP use cases
Different data types need not be forced into a single data model
Different use cases need not be forced into a single CAP model

blocks.title: Dealing with multiple databases need not complicate the application
bullets: Abstract away the CRUD APIs into a separate layer
Provide a single API for persisting to multiple databases synchronously
Provide different APIs for querying data for different use cases
Effectively create a Unified Data Repository

blocks.title: How to manage Synchronization?
bullets: OODEBE: Accion Labs's platform for Polyglot Persistence Synchronization

slides.subtitle: Polyglot Persistence Platform

content.text: Provides APIs that abstract away the complexity of multiple databases
Handles synchronization with a flexible consistency model for each use case
Provides horizontal scalability without compromising performance
Allows easy addition of new database engines to handle new data types or use cases

bullets: Provides a single API for persisting to multiple databases synchronously
Provides customizable APIs for querying data for different use cases
Ready-to-use processor plugins for most popular database engines
Ready-to-use API controllers for typical use cases such as batch and online operations
blocks.title: Simplicity

bullets: Application-specific APIs can be created with simple configuration files
Logical Locking to handle error recovery from any individual database operation failure
Batch as well as online synchronization with automatic prioritization of online operations
Coordination between processors using tightly coupled websockets or loosely coupled message queue
blocks.title: Flexibility

bullets: High speed synchronization using asynchronous I/O calls to each database API
Horizontally scalable - can distribute processors over a cluster of nodes
Kanban Queues to balance processing rates of different processor modules
Prioritization of online operations so that batch operations do not affect performance
blocks.title: Scalability

bullets: Integration of new database engines via custom-built processor plugins
Micro-services architecture with each processor acting as a service
Customizable controllers to orchestrate application specific APIs
Liberal open source license allows ownership of custom processors and controllers
Accion provides customization and support for OODEBE
